Teruyuki Mizuno

I am a tenure-track assistant professor at the Graduate School of Humanities and Sciences at Ochanomizu University, Tokyo. I am a theoretical linguist working on natural language semantics and pragmatics.

Prior to joining Ochanomizu University, I completed my PhD in linguistics in 2023 at the University of Connecticut, under the supervision of Stefan Kaufmann.

At Ochanomizu, I organize a joint seminar on formal semantics with Bekki Lab.

CV (June 2024)

Pronoun: he/him

Research Output (Last Update: June 2024)

Dissertation

  • Mizuno, Teruyuki. 2023. Counterfactual expressions: An investigation into their structures and meanings. Doctoral Dissertation, University of Connecticut, Storrs. (link)
    • Committee: Stefan Kaufmann (chair), Jon Gajewski, Magdalena Kaufmann

Modality and conditionals

  • Mizuno, Teruyuki. A formal semantics for Japanese counterfactuals. in revision.
  • Mizuno, Teruyuki. The structures and meanings of might-counterfactuals: a view from Japanese. Accepted with minor revisions for Linguistics and Philosophy.
  • Mizuno, Teruyuki. 2024. Strategies for Anderson conditionals: their implications for the typology of O-marking and X-marking. Semantics and Pragmatics 17(8). (early access)
  • Mizuno, Teruyuki and Stefan Kaufmann. 2022. Past-as-Past in counterfactual desire reports: a view from Japanese. Proceedings of SALT 32. (link)
  • Mizuno, Teruyuki. 2021. Q-particles in embedded declaratives, mood, and clausal complementation. Proceedings of SALT 31. (link)
  • Mizuno, Teruyuki and Stefan Kaufmann. 2019.Â Past-as-Past in Japanese counterfactuals. Proceedings of CLS 54, pp.309-324.

Ellipsis

  • Mizuno, Teruyuki. Argument ellipsis as topic deletion. Accepted with minor revisions for Natural Language & Linguistic Theory.
  • Mizuno, Teruyuki and Michael Yoshitaka Erlewine 2017. Constraints on contrast sluicing. Japanese/Korean Linguistics 24.
